humbugzilla wrote:

> I'm just getting into JUnit. Initially I was sceptical, but am
> becoming sold on it. This is one consideration which is bothering me.
> 
> Let me hastily insert a newbie warning here - I have _not_ read all
> the documentation, nor have I tried and understood even all the
> choices available when creating testcases and testsuites. However, I
> am finding useful benefit from JUnit so far and I'm motivated to take
> it further. To some extent, I'm beating a path for others in my team.
> 
> Java is write-once-run-anywhere - right? However, some of us need to
> test platform specific behaviour, for example, classes that only run
> in Windows or some other environment.
> 
> Has anyone written up or done any work with JUnit in this area?
> 
> At the moment, I'm envisaging something in a testcase/testsuite
> setUp() method where I have some means of checking the the test code
> is being run in the correct environment - this may mean checking
> system properties or some external property such as environment
> variables. If the environment isn't what I need for the tests to be
> valid, then I want JUnit to accept a special fail() which says to
> JUnit - don't run _any_ of the tests in this testcase/testsuite.
> 
> There's no point in running them because they won't be valid tests in
> the incorrect environment, so I don't want to see a whole bunch of
> fails because they shouldn't have been run.

I would recommend doing this through shell scripting, rather than in 
JUnit. Your script would simply choose not to launch the JUnit test 
runner under the "wrong" conditions.
